product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: **PLEASE READ BEFORE BUYING**
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 19, 2022
options: Style: 24" 75Hz Blue Light Shift | Pattern: Monitor
text: I have bought sceptre monitors in the past, and I stand by them as a great budget monitor company if you want something that's reliable and inexpensive. I purchased these monitors as secondary monitors and vertical monitors for my setup. From my experience, I knew that these monitors would be good for work other than gaming, so I primarily use them for watching videos, discord, or just as an extra screen for when I am doing work. I overall enjoy these monitors, but I have two major issues that I had first when I got them.I love the monitors, and they could be a 5-star product if they tweaked a couple of things. I will talk first about the main advantages of the monitors first. Firstly, for $150, you are getting a monitor with decent viewing angles and a good size with 75hz refresh rate viewing. For the price, it is a very good monitor alone for office or schoolwork. It does its job very well and anybody who is doing basic work or maybe some console gaming would have a good experience with these monitors. Furthermore, they are VESA mount* (more on that below), and it has a good display, with a speaker that although quiet, does the job well without sounding blown out. Overall, it is a good monitor, and anybody who wants something basic will enjoy this monitor.Here are the cons from my experience, as it had a couple off the start. I first opened the box to find that it talks about its return policy on the box. This was extremely concerning since it is almost impossible to send this monitor back. Please keep everything (including box and packaging materials) for the first month you own the monitor. The second issue I had was the mounting brackets you get with the monitor. For one thing, the monitor uses a separate monitor arm, that is screwed into a bracket that comes out of the monitor. If you plan on not using any desk mounts or VESA mounting, then you will have no problem with this monitor. However, I wanted to mount this monitor to a VESA desk mount to use as a vertical monitor. My first issue came when I tried to mount the monitor, when I tried to mount the monitor to the arm by screwing in the screws provided with the arm. The first issue comes with the hardware included with the monitor, there are four standoffs and two monitor screws, but the arm needed four screws, so we already are set back. I found some old monitor screws that fit, and when I mounted the monitor, I realized that the monitor wouldn't fit due to the bracket secured on the back, which sticks out of the monitor to make more viewing angles. Again, this won't be an issue for those who are planning on not using any VESA mounting, however, it makes the process a lot more difficult for those who are planning on doing any mounting of their monitor with a third party device. It took me like 20 minutes before I realized that the standoffs that are included are for VESA mounting, which although makes some sense, also makes me question why to include the mounting bracket externally when it could have been included inside of the monitor since there is a cutout section that fits it.I see this question a lot, and I feel that I should address it here for those who want to game on this monitor: get a different monitor. First, this monitor is a 75hz 5ms, meaning it refreshes the screen 75 times in one second, and it responds 5ms after the information has been sent by the PC. There are plenty of 144hz monitors with a 1ms response time for this price, and I recommend that you look for something at that price. If you want something to game on for the long run, get a 144hz monitor at the same price, it'll work better overall, and be around the same budget.Overall I highly enjoy this monitor. I give it four stars since it works very well for what I need it to do, and although it has its flaws I wouldn't want another monitor. It could have been five stars, only if the price was a little bit cheaper. The price does go up with the blue light shift that occurs, but the $133 option is still a little overpriced, I would personally price this around $115 and it would be the ultimate monitor for the price. Overall, if you want a monitor for office work, then please consider this, it's a great monitor.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: I'm astonished with the quality of this monitor.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 12, 2023
text: The monitor is very easy to set up and use. It has a sleek and thin design that looks great on my desk. It has two HDMI ports and one VGA port that allow me to connect multiple devices.The monitor has a stunning picture quality and performance. It has a full HD resolution (1920x1080) that delivers crisp and clear images. It has a 75Hz refresh rate that provides smooth and fluid motion. It also has a fast response time (5ms) that eliminates ghosting and blurring.I use this monitor for both gaming and work, and it has exceeded my expectations. I couldn't have reached Radiant in Valorant without this monitor (P.S. I was using a 1400x900 before this).Absolutely great for the price. I didn't expect it to be this good.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: 1 Annoying trait costs it a Star
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 18, 2023
options: Style: 24" 75Hz Blue Light Shift | Pattern: Monitor
text: I love this little monitor for the price. Perfect for using as an extended desktop for a laptop with an HDMI cable. Great picture quality and the ability to tweak the blue light for nighttime usage. The one thing I cannot figure out how to fix, that costs it 5 stars is that when the current input (HDMI 1) which is plugged into the laptop goes on sleep mode, the input automatically shifts to input 2 (HDMI with a Firestick). The process to switch it back is relatively simple but requires multiple button pushes on the back of the screen and if input 1 is not active immediately will switch right back to input 2. A remote would have made this process a lot easier, but this does not support one.  Same goes with volume.  Overall I am glad I purchased it, but not as good as it could have been.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: A Decent Option with Disappointing Sound and Design
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 27, 2023
text: First of all, let me just say that this monitor is so thin, I'm pretty sure I could snap it in half with my bare hands if I wanted to. But don't worry, I won't do that (yet).The good news is that the picture quality is pretty decent. I mean, it's not like I'm watching a movie on a 4K TV or anything, but for the price, I guess I can't complain too much. The 75Hz refresh rate is also nice, although it's not like I'm playing any games that require lightning-fast reflexes or anything. I'm mostly just using this monitor to watch cat videos on YouTube.Now, onto the bad news. First of all, the built-in speakers are a joke. They sound like they're coming from a tin can that's been kicked around by a bunch of angry toddlers. I mean, I wasn't expecting Bose-quality sound or anything, but come on, Sceptre, you can do better than this.And speaking of sound, let's talk about the noise this thing makes. Every time I turn it on, it emits a high-pitched whine that sounds like a thousand tiny mosquitoes buzzing around my head. I've tried everything to make it stop, but no matter what I do, it just won't go away. So now, every time I want to use my monitor, I have to wear noise-cancelling headphones just to avoid going insane.Finally, let's talk about the design. I mean, I get that it's supposed to be "professional" and all, but come on, Sceptre, you can do better than this bland machine black color. Why not make it hot pink or neon green or something? At least then it would be a conversation starter.Overall, I'm giving this monitor two out of five stars. It's not the worst thing I've ever bought, but it's definitely not the best either. If you're looking for a cheap monitor that won't make your ears bleed, this might be a decent option. Just be prepared to wear earplugs and invest in some bright-colored paint.The best monitor parameters depend on your specific needs and preferences. However, here are some common parameters to consider when choosing a monitor:1. Screen size: The size of the monitor determines how much screen real estate you have to work with. Consider how much desk space you have and how much screen size you need to comfortably work.2. Resolution: The resolution of the monitor determines how sharp and clear the image is. Higher resolutions like 4K or 1440p offer sharper images, but also require more powerful hardware to run smoothly.3. Refresh rate: The refresh rate of a monitor determines how many times the screen updates per second. Higher refresh rates like 144Hz or 240Hz offer smoother motion and are preferred for gaming and other fast-paced activities.4. Response time: The response time of a monitor determines how quickly the pixels can change from one color to another. Lower response times like 1ms or 2ms are preferred for gaming and other fast-paced activities.5. Panel type: The panel type of a monitor determines the color accuracy, contrast, and viewing angles. There are three main types of panels: IPS, TN, and VA. IPS panels offer the best color accuracy and viewing angles, while TN panels offer the fastest response times. VA panels offer the best contrast.6. Connectivity: The connectivity options of a monitor determine what devices you can connect to it. Common connectivity options include HDMI, DisplayPort, and USB-C.7. Ergonomics: The ergonomics of a monitor determine how easily you can adjust its position. Consider features like adjustable height, tilt, and swivel to find a comfortable viewing angle.Overall, the best monitor parameters for you will depend on your specific needs and intended use.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: A Budget Monitor that Mostly Works OK - Not Recommended
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 9, 2022
text: I have had this monitor for only a few days, and I am not very impressed with it.  The monitor control buttons being in the back where you have to blindly feel for them and just remember which one is which is a terrible design.  All of my other monitors have the buttons under the front edge where they are so much easier to use.  Having two HDMI inputs is nice, but the actual steps to switch between inputs are cumbersome, and the speed to switch screens is slow.  Not a big deal for the occasional change, but if you want to switch between inputs frequently while sitting at your desk, this is not a good monitor.The worst thing MAY be the speakers  - they are absolute garbage in both sound quality and volume (but see the last paragraph about the screen flashing on and off).  Turning up the volume in system settings on the monitor does absolutely nothing to increase the sound at any setting above 50%.  What you can hear sounds like a 20-year old laptop sitting on the floor of a school bathroom - tiny, echo-y, and very hard to understand.  I have several other monitors with built-in speakers, and these are by far the worst I have every heard.  The other monitor sitting next to this one sounds absolutely fantastic by comparison.  I have good speakers on my desk, but I was hoping to get rid of them to save some space - no way with this monitor!The picture quality seems decent - sitting side-by-side with a much older HP monitor of the same size and definition, both displays seem similar in brightness and color accuracy on an average browser window, but when comparing a screen with lots of high-contrast dark and light, this monitor is very washed out.  I have tried adjusting picture and color settings, and nothing improves the lack of a good black and poor contrast.  In fact, increasing the contrast setting just makes the blacks even MORE gray!But I am quite worried about the reliability.I set this up yesterday and left it on with the laptop in sleep mode all night - I didn't make any setting adjustments.  This morning the laptop woke fine and the monitor came on as expected, but as soon as I reached around the side of the monitor to find the control buttons, the monitor started flashing on and off, like a light with a loose or broken wire.  When I pulled my hand back, it was fine, but I could not touch the monitor at all without it flashing on and off.  The power light was not going on and off, so it was not that, and I tried changing the input to both HDMI ports with no difference.  Once I opened up the OSD, the flashing stopped as long as the OSD was up, but started again when I hit the Exit button.  After about 15 minutes of playing with the settings, I noticed that the monitor was no longer showing the problems when I touched it.  And it seems to still be working normally about an hour later.  But I am extremely worried about what was causing this issue, and how long it will be before it starts again.  If I wiggle the HDMI cable on the back of the monitor, it sometimes blanks out (but no where near as touchy  as it was in the beginning), so I guess the fault is there and I will have to return the unit.  What a pain.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: I am extremelly impressed with this monitor! Great buy specially for gaming!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 24, 2018
text: I have a GTX 1060 laptop, set up is easy and there was no need for me to calibrate anything, I even dare say this monitor looks better than my own laptop screen at 1080p.At first i thought it didn not support 75Hz and the colors were washed out and it was too bright, also on the nvidia panel it said 1080p at 60Hz however this is what you gotta do to fix it."CALIBRATION"1. Connect via HDMI2. Open Display settings and make sure that they are set so that only the 2nd display is turned on, do not put duplicate or extend.3. Open Nvidia control panel and go to "Change Resolution"4. You will see two lists, one will say HD, UHD etc, the other one at the bottom will say "PC", (changing the first list will project your laptop screen to the second screen however your laptop is 60Hz and the monitor is 75Hz that is why its limited to 60Hz and colors are washed out, changing the second list will basically use your laptop to power up the monitor at full 75Hz 1080p with the right color calibration.)5. On list two "PC" change the resolution to 1080p and 75HzAnd there you go, now you can use your 75Hz monitor for gaming, make sure to change the settings indvidually in games to 75Hz or they will still run at 60Hz and the colors will be washed out.Now onto the review*** REVIEW ***The screen resolution is full 1920x1080p at 75Hz, the colors are very accurate, it looks no where near like a TN panel, I would say its in between a TN panel and an IPS panel but closer to IPS.It comes with speakers which are ok for the price but I recommend headphones or your own speakers which are probably better if you got this for gaming.This is what comes in the package- Monitor- 4 screws for mounting- Two screws for setting up the monitor (non adjustable height(- HDMI to VGA cable- VGA to VGA cableI really recommend this monitor even if not for gaming, its a great price for what you get and it even comes with two cables.However one thing to note is that the difference between 60Hz and 75Hz is hard to notice in games. Playing Witcher 3 and Rise of Tomb Raider at locked in 75FPS wasn't anything much more amazing than 60FPS. However it is still an improvement.One last thing to confider if you’re debating on a 75Hz vs 144Hz monitor- If you have a graphics card such as the GTX 770,970,1060 Most games (witcher, call of duty, battlefield wont go back 80 fps on ultra / high graphics) so you wont be able to take advantage of a 144Hz monitor, so I suggest this one. UNLESS you play on medium/low settings.- If you have a graphics card such as a GTX 770,780,980,1070 and above, I suggest the 144Hz monitor since these can run most tiles at well above 100FPS so you can take advantage of the monitor.*** UPDATE ***Earlier on the review I said the difference between 60Hz and 75Hz was negligible, I take it back.I played on my laptop which is limited to 60Hz and it feels bad and slugish compared to 75Hz, once you go higher refresh rate you can never go backIts one of those things you dont realise until its taken away, great improvement.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Great picture, speakers almost non-existent.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 2, 2023
options: Style: 24" 75Hz Blue Light Shift | Pattern: Monitor
text: Lighting in my room dulls down the picture, but the screens look great. I've had these 2 monitors for close on a year now, wanted to wait to write my review to make sure they worked well. With these two monitors added to my setup, it's much easy to multitask and use two separate systems once. I use one for playing console games and the other for PC use like video editing.  The resolution is great, allowing me to read small text/chat boxes in my MMORPG games without pixels making the text distorted. Refresh rates is on point and even when using Live View on Capture software there's no lag on the screen!  The side buttons are easily navigated once you know what button does what and having 3 (two HDMI, 1 VGA) video inputs means you can change sources if you need to without much trouble. The bezel around the monitors are low profile enough that the screens don't seem overly large without giving you plenty of viewing surface.  The biggest downside for me is that the speakers for these monitors are in the back of the monitor near the bottom and are incredibly weak! At 100, the volume is still so low I can't hear very well, so I'm forced to use headphones which starts to fatigue the head and ears after several hours of editing. The monitors do come with audio jacks in the back, but I feel that speaker quality shouldn't force us to default to external speakers/headphones.  If you don't mind wearing headphones, or play games with headphones for Party Chat/game audio it's not a deal breaker, and as I said I mostly edit videos/ play games on these so headphones are part of the whole deal, it'd just be nice to not be forced into headsets when I don't want to.  Other than that ONE issue, these are great monitors and considering the price (especially if you're getting more than one at once like I did) I'm more than happy to deal with headphones. Highly recommend with cautionary information about built in speakers.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Good Monitor for Office Work
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 22, 2022
options: Style: 24" 75Hz Blue Light Shift | Pattern: Monitor
text: Let's be honest here, this is not a gaming monitor, despite claiming it can run at 75Hz. This is a budget monitor thru and thru. But the picture quality is good, viewing angle is good and color is good. If you're using this for office work or watching 1080p videos, it's actually perfect.Now the cons. This monitor's extremely light weight. The base is all plastic and carries no weight like your normal and high-end monitors. The ports are facing straight back rather than pointing down, which puts strain on the cable and ports. The power cable is rather flimsy and thin, I'm afraid the interior wire will break after repeated connect and disconnect. The last thing that falls short with this monitor is the speakers are weak, like really weak. You best get a sound bar or speaker.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Not familiar with this brand, but went with them due to reviews and price...no regrets
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 4, 2022
text: I have two very old, inexpesive 18" monitors that have lasted a very long time, but one of them started flaking out when hooked up to my hub.  My office has much larger ones and thought this was a sign I should finally upgrade and get the same screen size at home as I do in the office.  But since my old monitors lasted a LONG time without paying a lot, I wanted to repeat that experience.  Lots of research and talking to other people led me to similar conclusion:  not a lot out there at a cheap price for larger sizes for people that just need a large working screen and not concerned about graphics and gaming.I had not heard of the Scepter brand before so I was a bit dubious.  But as I talked about my search with others, some programmers mentioned they HAD heard of them and were reputable.  They were about the best price and reviews largely good, so the programmer endorsement was what I needed to pull the trigger.I'm very happy with these monitors!  Easy to set up.  Great resolution and color.  SO MUCH LIGHTER than my old ones.  I had to adjust the tension in my mounting arms accordingly.  I went with the standard, automatice calibration and haven't felt the need to fiddle with additional settings.  I'm an account/project manager that deals in spreadsheets, project management tools, Microsoft suite (Excel, Work, Outlook), and Adobe Creative Suite (Acrobat, Dreamweaver, Photoshop), and other custom tools for digital design, programming and management.One thing I liked, and needed, is that the mounting screwholes on the back of the monitors are on the BOTTOM of the screen...rather than the middle or towards the top, which seems to be more standard.  This actually helped me get the monitors to the height I wanted with the mount I have without haveing to replace that too.  Works great for me, but might be a consideration for others, depending on how you plan to mount them.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Great monitor but with a few annoying quirks.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2022
text: A quick word of advice to everyone who buys this monitor:  when you first hook it up to your computer, you will find that the screen (esp text, when scrolling) gets quite blurry and the colors might seem blotchy.  I was thinking that the monitor was defective when I saw it, but, after some homework, figured out that the problem is caused by faulty "overdrive" feature (or maybe not faulty?  never actually saw this feature before).  The control for "Overdrive" is under "System" and it's set to "medium" by default.  Turn it off.  Then the problem of blurry screen will go away and after that, the monitor is great.  (While I can't speak to the durability of this particular product, I've had generally excellent experience with Scepter monitors, all of which (I've had 4, including this one) were very durable over 3-4 years that I've used them.  At minimum, they products are worth it, IMHO.*Original review below:The short version is that the monitor is great (it is, fwiw, the most economical FHD monitor available), but some of the features don't seem to be working quite right.  One specific problem that came out right away was that the "Overdrive" feature is not working properly:  when you hook it up to your computer, you will find that objects on the monitor get blurry momentarily when you scroll.  After some searching, I found out that this is due to the overdrive feature that's supposed to speed up the response time...except, in this case, it's just making objects blurrier as they move with the mouse scroll.  The overdrive is set to "medium" in the factory setting.  You want to turn it off as the first thing you do.  After that, you should be happy.

It's not a terrible monitor for what you paid for. In some ways it's better than the LG in some ways, brighter whites and slightly more saturated darks. One issue I have with it is that I can't get the 75Hz refresh rate that is on the box and in the manual. Another issue I have is that it's not as crisp as the LG, when watching videos the image is slightly more crisp and cooler as far as color. Overall this monitor is a great beginner monitor if you buy it at the $90 that I did, just make sure that if you are running a dual monitor setup that you have a stand that let's you adjust the height of the monitors individually because the VESA mount is low on the monitor and that most likely will put it at a higher viewing angle than your other monitor... trust me I know.

title: Great value
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2022
text: One aggravating fault with this set.  Netflix and Hulu apps crash after a couple weeks using.  The only fix is go to settings, find apps in advanced settings, clear cache and data.  Great, it worked, but now have to login to apps again.  I have read if you don't update to latest firmware you won't experience the issue.  I dunno, I let it upgrade and am not sure I want to reset to defaults and skip the upgrade.  I suppose if I get aggravated enough I will try it.Enough rant about the single flaw.  Picture quality is awesome once correctly calibrated.  I love the android integration and simplicity connecting to my Samsung Note 10+.  The remote works great in spite the fact it feels like an empty shell.  No worries.  If you lose it you can operate it with your phone.  With voice if you want.  Upshot, for the money, in spite the one aggravation, I would definitely buy this set again.

text: I so love this monitor and its performance that,  since 2018, I have purchased 7 of these monitors.  4 were for a home office in NJ and 2 were for a home office in FL for vacations.  I gave away the 4 in NJ, prior to moving to FL.  Thinking that I still had 4 in FL, I gave 1 of those to my brother for his security system.  Upon arrival, I realized I only originally had 2 in FL and now I was left with 1.  I struggled with 1 monitor for 4 months.  I wouldn't purchase another because the pandemic supply and demand had pushed prices too high for my retirement income and I wanted the monitors to match.  I happen to see this one at a discount which brought it into my budget range so I jumped on it.  It isn't much more than my 2018 purchases however, the last few I bought for FL all have built-in speakers and 2 HDMI ports.  Whaaaat?  So very much worth the price and I highly recommend this monitor.  The pictures are wonderful.  Can't comment on sound since I just found out that they have speakers and haven't used those yet.  I can only assume they are basic speakers for video cons.  5 stars and 2 thumbs up from me.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Panel is great, engineering sucks.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2023
text: Okay, the panel itself is excellent, bright, sharp, and easy to read. That covers the good stuff, and if that was all, I would be giving this a 5-star review. However, I purchased this specifically to VESA mount it to a desk-mounted arm. As a VESA mountable monitor, it sucks. The mounting for the included stand completely blocks the VESA mount. I had to literally cut the stand mount off of the monitor to fit the VESA mounting plate onto the monitor. If you want to use a wall or arm mount for your monitor, DO NOT get this monitor. Whatever engineer approved the position and use of this stand mount did a horrible job. Again, this monitor is unsuitable for VESA mount unless you are willing to physically modify (i.e., cut the damn mount off with a hacksaw, thus eliminating your warranty) the monitor before use.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Pretty good for general use although I wouldn't exactly rave about them
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 7, 2020
text: I purchased two of these monitors for a dual display home office setup and they function similarly. Black levels are poor, picture quality is acceptable and backlighting is shockingly very even. The led backlighting either isn't zoned or at least doesn't strike me as zoned (I don't remember whether or not this was advertised as zoned but I suspect it wasn't). With all that said, I didn't expect these to be amazing monitors. As general purpose 24" budget displays these are pretty good. I haven't used them to game so I can't attest to the sync on the 75hz mode.I purchased these for a home office setup where I'm looking at emails, spreadsheets, command shells and web browsers all day peppered with the odd VTC call. These do those tasks admirably. I'm sitting 34-44 inches away from these screens 10-12 hours a day and my eyes haven't started to feel any strain so that's a plus.Build quality on one of them is displaying (ha pun not intended) a bit of bezel separation. I only noticed this about 2 weeks into ownership but it isn't enough for me to go through the hassle of unmounting it from my monitor arm and swapping it out if an RMA were approved, but it is enough for me to drop a star.I will also note that there is no real re-enforcement to this chasis. When mounted to an adjustable monitor arm I would recommend only rotating,swinging or pivoting by grabbing opposing bezel corners rather than opposing bezel edge as otherwise you will introduce a bit of flex.  This is something I always check when mounting new monitors for the first time and holy heck did these not even pass my minimum comfort zone for rigidity on even the lightest adjustment when going by the edges - corners only for sure.Other than the bezel separation these panels hit my expectations for a inexpensive general purpose 24" displays with dual HDMI inputs. I haven't performed any calibration on these displays so my "acceptable" rating on their picture quality could potentially be improved upon and I've used preconfigured picture settings.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Good quality for the $'s. So far so good.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 8, 2022
text: Main reason for selecting this monitor was due to my desk having a limited space (mainly the height) for the monitor to be able to fit. I could actually fit a larger monitor in the space available, but it seems like they all have several inches of space between the bottom of the monitor and the stand it's mounted on and are not adjustable. Previously, I actually cut/modified a stand in order to fit a larger monitor in this space. Unfortunately the Sceptre monitor doesn't have an adjustable stand, but at least it has less useless area between the bottom of the monitor and bottom of the stand!I've only been using for about a month now but for a smaller low cost monitor the picture quality is quite good. At least I think so. Should mention that I'm using this for running older PC games (Age of Empires, Sims 3, GTR2, etc.), word processing, working with photos, etc. Driving sims like GTR2 and GT Legends might push the graphics limits but I'm not on You Tube streaming movies or online w/IRacing.I have an older set of speakers (from the friggin' 1980's that not only still work but work very well - Logitech makes/made some awesome stuff!) so no idea how good the monitor's internals work but should be nice to have them as a backup.Overall it appears to be perfect for my needs but YMMV. Be sure and do your homework, like I did, before making your choice.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Works so far...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 2, 2020
text: Purchased two 24 inch monitors to hang on a dual monitor desk stand, for home and light business work.So far- they work as advertised; the only thing that I am concerned about is the power supply- most monitors typically have those three prong heavy duty power cords that go to the back of the monitor with the power systems built inside the monitor itself; these  24 inch monitors do not have this but instead have what I would describe as a 'cell phone charger' that plugs into the wall instead.  The chargers get somewhat warmer to the touch, but not hot, yet,  after a couple of days of use. It makes me wonder if this is going to fail over time,  as these types of charger setups usually do - or if and when they will get warmer  to the touch, etc. The cords leading up from the plug in wall 'charger/pack' is small as well- I am not an engineer but it appears that they are as minimal as possible and are running the converted power ( D.C.?)  to the back of the monitor, which is also causing me some concern.  They are not what I consider heavy duty by any means- more along the lines of a cellphone cord strength,  running from the wall to the back of the monitors. I assume this is a design so they can change the chargers out for different country power systems. etc.At the end of the day- I will keep the monitors but will touch the packs from time to time. Hopefully the wires do not move much as I would fear a short circuit that you get with a cell phone cord with a lot of use.Buyers will need to keep the boxes as it says specifically states on the boxes that they are needed for any warranty returns, etc.BTW - it did come with a generic HDMI cord, a small set up manual, 4 screws and 4 extension screws for mounting options; the screws are minimal as well...

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: For the price, excellent monitor.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 11, 2021
text: Have had this monitor, and used it everyday for work and play, for the last 8 months or so.  Out of the box, I noticed that its pretty light, frame is minimal and pretty thin. Has multiple mounting options with the stand, or the standard bolt pattern on the back for use with a desk mount.  Included one HDMI cable.  Was pretty much plug and play.  I opted to adjust the RBG values slightly to match the hue of my somewhat older monitors (I use a triple display option for work).I like that it has two HDMI inputs. I have my work computer and my personal computer for gaming hooked up to both HDMI ports and can switch the input as necessary.  It does auto-detect the input connection; if both machines are off and you power one on, it will switch to that input automatically, which is a pretty common, but very nice feature.  I do with the button were placed in a slightly more accessible place.  Currently, this monitor is in the middle of the 3 that I use.  If I do need to press the buttons, they're on the back and I have to move them around; it would be helpful if they were top or bottom mounted, but I suppose that would cause the screen to be thicker to accommodate buttons on the narrow side of the frame.  So not a huge complaint, just a wish-list item.Picture quality is sharp, has pretty good contrast.  I have the 24" size and the native resolution defaults to 1920 x 1080.  Pretty good blacks.  Pretty good color presets.Overall, I have no major complaints at this point.  Its a good size for a home-use, office display and at $100, was a pretty good deal.  Would recommend to anyone looking for a good monitor on a budget.

title: Check Your Monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 13, 2022
text: I purchased this as a second monitor for work. It was purchased as new. I finally had a chance to open and setup. The monitor display just shows white with black and/or gray lines. I pressed the menu button to change the display and nothing happened.Unfortunately, I am outside of the return period - contacted seller via Amazon and was told to contact Sceptre.I contacted Sceptre customer service and was told to complete the warranty return form. I completed that and have to wait up to 48 hours for the return form. Guess what? I am responsible for the shipping and insurance. Go figure.. It’s probably not going to be worth me sending it back depending on the cost.If you order, be sure to check everything out before your return period expires.Update 11/14/22: I was able to return the monitor and Sceptre sent me a free return shipping label. After sending pictures of the non-working monitor, they eventually sent me another monitor (received last week). This time I opened the box to check out the new monitor, and it works (picture looked good). I updated my star rating by two more stars since I was able to return the monitor and get another one. Thank you Sceptre!

The colors are very nice and bright though which is nice and the images on the main part of the screen are very clear. product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Just calm down, It's was only $104.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 19, 2020
text: If you are rating this like you ordered a $500 top of the line gaming monitor, then it's YOU that has issues, not the product. For under $120 this monitor well surpassed my expectations initially, as for longevity, we'll see. Great picture quality, thin appearance, and pretty small bezels. Came with HDMI cord (wasn't expecting that) and spacers for wall mounts/other mounting kits. Usable UI for adjustments if that's your thing. I honestly just set it up, plugged it in and bobs you're uncle. Again, it was only $104 when I ordered it, so this review is based on that. What else can be said? 24 inches is 24 inches, 75 hertz is 75 hertz, colors are colored and cords do cord things! For the price, it's definitely recommended and expectations where exceeded. Don't buy a monitor under $120 and try to review it like a $500 god-like gaming accessory.So to recap, the monitor monitors, cords cord, and the stand stands. Cough into you elbow, stop driving 100mph and don't go to Walmart just to browse the electronics during a pandemic.Update- Jan 2021-turns out that you shouldn't sit near anything valuable while in vr. Still worked great even after I had smacked/punched it accidentally in vr......well at least the first 8 or 9 times anyway. The last hit did it in for good unfortunately but clearly not at all any fault of the brand. So, don't tell yourself you'll not do something again(sit to close to the monitor) but then repeatedly do it again and again expecting a different outcome. Wait, what's the definition of insanity again? 🤔

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Good for the money, BUT...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2020
text: This is a fairly good 24" 1920x1080 60p monitor. Easily configurable to a myriad of needs.That said, it is a TOTAL PAIN to mount.Now, if you want to simply use the included pedestal base, fine. No problem, the installation is fairly simple and straightforward.The REAL problem comes when you want to use the VESA mount. I suppose if you intend to use a variable frame wall mount, it should go well. It's mounting on a swing arm bracket that proved difficult. If you do not have 1/2" spacers and long mounting screws, you will have to take more drastic measures to make the mounting plate fit properly. I need about 30 minutes, a Dremel-style power tool and a metal-cutting wheel to cut the pedestal mount bracket off, then, using a metal-grinding bit to smooth out the rough bits. If you do this carefully, it will go quickly and cleanly. You just have to be careful and TAKE YOUR TIME.Once I was able to mount mine, it worked beautifully from the minute I turned it on. It has a line of buttons up the right-hand rear, with the power button on the bottom.I have this connected to an Acer Nitro 5 17" tablet with dedicated nVidia GTX1650 4GB video card, so I can us my laptop with a wireless mouse and keyboard without squinting at a typical laptop display. I have it positioned, so that I can raise the lid without bumping into it. It is quite lightweight, as well.

title: Good deal - speakers are the only disappointment
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
text: I was looking for a good, inexpensive monitor for someone else and this fit the bill.The picture quality is fine for the specs given.  In fact, I was pleased to see a good tilt function and the HDMI cable included.  It  even includes a small screw driver for attaching the base.One minor item is that I wish the power switch had been on the front.  For the older, less tech savvy user, it can be good to have the power switch (and maybe others) on the front instead of tucked far behind on the back.  I had not thought of that while shopping.The bigger disappointment was the speakers.  I knew to not set high expectations but I thought for sure they would be better than a cheap laptop's speakers for youtube and zoom.  In fact, they were significantly worse than the 15" Dell Inspiron's built-in speakers.  For the older, hard of hearing person, this was quite a disappointment.I would say it is a good buy as long as you are not counting on the speakers.  I would have gladly traded the screwdriver and HDMI cables for slightly better speakers.Still, overall it exceeded expectations at this price point.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Great for productivity, perhaps not for gaming or media creation and consumption
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 2, 2019
text: Well, the old adage, "You get what you pay for", holds true in this case.Physical Appearance------------------------The monitor looks nice, with thin bezels and a simple raised, "metallic" sceptre logo at the bottom bezel. The stand is nothing to write home about, and only features tilt adjustment, not height adjustment. The monitor is surprisingly thin for this price point, and would be great VESA mounted, but I'm using the included stand.One thing I noticed is the sturdiness of the stand. My desk has some wiggle in it, and when typing I can visibly notice the monitor wiggle back and forth a bit, which can be annoying.Performance----------------This is where things go down hill. Rather than belabor these points, I'll bulletize:- Very noticeable backlight bleeding around the corners. I work in an IDE (i.e. fancy programming text editor) that uses a dark theme, so the backlight bleeding is very noticeable with the dark background- Washed out colors. Just general lack of vibrancy in the colors and muted overall- Color accuracy? visually, based on how washed out the colors are; I'm going to wager the color accuracy is not good. NOTE: I haven't measured, but let's be real here.- Speakers. It has builtin speakers. They work. That's about the best compliment I can give them. Use headphones.Overall Opinion--------------------I personally got this monitor for my home office. I work as a software engineer and work from home frequently. This is my second monitor, alongside my 5+ year old 900p Gateway TFT LCD monitor.First off, my old monitor performs better in all the above mentioned short comings. Vibrant color and no visible backlight bleeding. I don't know how much the gateway monitor cost originally, as I got it from an old neighbor who was moving out :)So, even compared to monitors of years gone by, this thing is underwhelming.That all said, for productivity use, I can't complain that much. The muted nature actually seems to reduce eye strain perhaps. As we say in the software world, "It's not a bug, it's a feature!". The backlight bleed, while annoying, is easily forgotten once I'm actually focused working on something. Color accuracy and vibrancy doesn't matter to me. My general use case is: programming, IM, email, documentation writing/reading, web browsing, and general productivity usage.Conclusion-------------At the end of the day, it's a 24" 1080p monitor for just shy of $100. If you're planning on using it for gaming, photo/video editing, general media consumption, or anything in that area; I'd suggest spending a bit more for a better monitor.On the other hand, if you just want something for general office/productivity usage. I mean, it's under $100 and it works. So I'd definitely recommend it for that use case.

text: Very nice monitor.  You can't ask for too much considering the price.  My only caveat is that the monitor ALWAYS auto-detects the active input. title: Possibly the best budget 1080p monitor for everything

text: I've been stuck using an old ASUS monitor that used a 16:10 aspect ratio for years, and since I finished building my PC recently, I really wanted to get my own 1080p monitor with bright colors and great viewing angles.And that's when I stumbled upon this....I've tried Sceptre products before (as my mother owns a curved monitor from them and it works really well), so I was honestly hoping for a decent monitor that have some cut corners to make the price reasonable, but man.... Was I astonished when I received it.Packaging was well and setup only took a maximum of 10 minutes. It also came with its own HDMI cable (that I didn't realize, so I have a spare just sitting on my desk xd) as well as a screwdriver that was really handy.Once I turned it on, I was blown away. Colors were bright and vivid, and the real estate on the monitor allows for lots of tabs being shown at once. The monitor also has Adaptive Sync, which helps with games running higher than 60 FPS not feel glitchy or slow. I played Destiny 2 on here, and it was just a smooth experience overall, and the viewing angles were great, thanks to it's IPS panel.If you're looking for a good IPS monitor that doesn't break the bank but gives amazing 1080p quality, then this is the monitor for you.

title: Caution on the E248W models manufactured in October 2021 - they fail just outside the warranty
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 30, 2023
text: These monitors started out great.  We have scads of other Sceptre monitors at our office.  All the other ones are well past two years old and doing just fine.  This set was a matching set of E248W units and were unlike our other purchases.  I have removed them from service at 14 months because they both started getting lines in them.  At first it was a just a few and out of any real area of concern, but again this was just outside the warranty period.  I cannot possibly be the only person who has had this happen.  Both failed the exact same way, with multiple colored lines on the top and bottom - increasing in number and severity over time.  I have since replaced them and Sceptre support states they're out of warranty.  They did cost less than $100 when purchased and that should have been a red flag to me.  You get what you pay for.

text: The screen quality is great, the 75hz is nice once you configure it, and the monitor itself has a clean form factor. My big problem with it is that the buttons on the side broke which caused the monitor to keep turning itself on and off (in the middle of use). It was very frustrating, and Amazon didn't want to replace it since I had already had it for awhile. Got in touch with the manufacturer and they wanted me to send it in to be fixed. They estimated a 4 to 6 week turnaround time. Why not just send me a new one and repair the old one? Anyway the screen is nice, but it has since gotten to the point where it just never turns off. I'm too scared to try to turn it off at this point because I'm pretty sure it's never going to turn back on.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: All around decent with a few shortcomings
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2020
text: I bought this monitor mainly for the attractive low price, like most Sceptre monitors. I wasn’t too fussed about the refresh rate of this monitor since this is a second monitor that isn’t used for gaming, mainly work/productivity. Looking at the pictures from Amazon I didn’t realize the low placement for the vesa mount, so it wouldn’t line up with my other monitor (Asus VG248qe) horizontally, so I decided to use the monitor in portrait mode being it was for work not gaming. My initial impressions were decent, colors were a bit washed out and undersaturated, but with some adjustments of the color settings the monitor looked decent and gets the job done considering what you pay for itA couple things to note:1. Not ideal for horizontal dual monitor setups with different monitors. Unless you check the VESA mount position on the other monitor or use one of the monitors in portrait mode, the monitors will be slightly askew2. Not ideal for gaming, unless you play casually every now and then and don’t care too much about frames or picture quality, mainly due to the reason of the low refresh rate, pity full colors, especially noticeable in deep blacks or darker colors, and whites which have a blue tone to them, and although it is a 1080p monitor it’s true resolution is questionable it has sort of a hazy grain no matter what I try and do to fix it.3. Because of the lack of a display port and the odd refresh rate cap you have to make sure you buy the right cable as VGA doesn’t have the ability to surpass 60hz and only certain HDMI cables can reach past 60hz so make sure you buy the right one.Summary: it’s an all around decent monitor, although I personally wouldn’t use it to game, it still has the potential to be decent in game. With this monitor you truly get what you pay for, if you plan on getting into gaming more seriously I say take the investment of getting a higher end monitor if possible as it’s 100% worth it, otherwise go for it

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Good for most things
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2020
text: I got this on a good price on here, as it filled a couple specific needs I had. I'm using this on a boat running navigation  software on a Raspberry Pi 4. For that purpose, it should work well. Screen has good clarity and does get rather bright when set. Including standoffs for vesa mounts to clear the stand mount is a nice addition. The speakers are a joke for anything but a very quiet home-desk where you're sitting less than 5' from it. They aren't very full sounding, and even at max volume they get drowned out by any background noise. Luckily having an audio out jack helps with this. The only other thing I would've liked to see though would be a remote to adjust the settings instead of having to reach around to the back. Until you have a feel for them, or keep the manual handy, you have to fumble a little to get through the menu. Even just a basic menu-up-down-enter remote would've been good.For the price, it's a decent 1080 monitor, very lightweight, and multiple inputs is great. If you want to use it for more than a monitor, add a cheap set of speakers and it'll do better. If you get a good sale on it, it just makes it better.

title: Great for HAMs, great picture, not glassy - low power
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
text: clear picture, not shiney, glassy like other units.We have 15-18 monitors, some which are 12vdc, some which are not.The problem we have with the RV 12vdc monitors/TVs  - the picture is reflective, shiney, hard to view at some angles.  These are easy to view, no real latency (studdering pictures), we watch HDMI videos on them, under WIN10 and ZORIN (unix like OS), both of them perform very nicely.Low Power consumption!Why these - because they will run off a 12v battery.  We lose power OFTEN - these will run a battery down to about 10VDC before they start flickering (battery is gasping it's last).  One is on my HAM Radio station, the other is on our Weather Station.  I need & use both.  These have been a very welcome solution to our power problem, so far, it's the only monitor that I can confidently recommend.The name brand monitors ... power hogs 150-250 watts each!.  These are cheap to run, 24/7... more like 50 watts or less.  Power consumption adds up FAST - it does with us.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Crisp, bright display with tinny speakers
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
text: Bought this monitor to put alongside my Sceptre E248W-1920R for a dual monitor setup. These were both quite lightweight and fit my dual monitor VESA mounts just fine. I got this model right on time for delivery and have been testing it out for its intended use in a home office setup. Been quite happy so far, so here is a review in light of having both of these models.Pros:1) Lightweight and has 4 VESA mounting screws, which make it perfect for fitting in dual monitor arm setups.2) Excellent and bright display which handles displaying online meeting video, training videos, and coding just fine.3) The price for value is pretty great, looking at alternatives for this size.Only cons here are:1) The sound is quite tinny, which is hinted at in the description as "office level audio".2) There is no remote, so any audio adjustments will be done awkwardly using the buttons behind the monitor for my setup. Tune it using your computer instead.3) Minor complaint, the frame of the monitor is plastic. I'm happier about the other model with its metal frame, which is magnetic.4) Again, minor: certain visual settings can only be accessed by choosing a "custom" video mode to access brightness, contrast, etc.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Cheapest monitor for a reason
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2023
text: I had this monitor for about 6 months before the screen just stopped working. I reached out to customer support via phone, we went through the troubleshooting process and confirmed it was a defective monitor and to email for a warranty claim.Once I emailed they made me go through the exact same process, and actually tried to suggest I installed the monitor incorrectly at first. After several emails, they finally said they’d replace the monitor.Their warranty replacement is different than most vendors. They require you to send their device back first. It took about two weeks for them to send me a box to ship the clearly broken monitor back. The first box they sent me was apparently lost by fedex, which just caused additional delays.I had to ask them three separate times to provide the return label. Why didn’t they just provide that in the box they sent me? Who knows.Once they finally received the monitor, I had to follow up with them AGAIN to ship out the new monitor.FedEx delivered the monitor to the wrong address. The support team currently is not providing any updates or resolutions to the issue.It’s been about two months since their monitor stopped working, and I still have no resolution. While I understand part of the challenge was with fedex, they’re the ones who chose to use them, and they are the ones who need to fix this.The experience with the support staff has been awful. They are slow to respond and make you jump through hoops to get anything done. I bought two monitors, one was faulty. So a 50% failure rate from my experience and terrible customer support. You get what you pay for.I have bought and used 4-5 Asus monitors. While they’re a little more expensive, I never had a single issue. I regret going with the cheapest option.

text: I absolutely love this monitor for my computer. I get great color and it is large enough that I can write this review without squinting at my screen. I put it on my laptop without a docking station and am able to use the computer with the lid closed thus saving my computer from spills. The sound quality is poor but that is minor as I have also purchased external speakers that create the sound I need to use my google voice program and listen to music through my Amazon music account. For everyday computing, this monitor is exceptional. I am very pleased that I purchased it and plan to buy another one for my wife this Christmas.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: My go-to for office monitors.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2018
text: Needed two new monitors for a new PC in the office. Went with this because it was the best value in terms of size vs price. I'd also purchased these for clients in the past and heard they were happy with them. After seeing the complaints about the colors being washed out, I gave my monitors away and decided if there were any problems with these I'd either live with it or fix it.Out of the box the monitors were fine. The only complaint I can come up with is that the VESA mounts are lower on the back due to the slim design. After looking at settings, I determined that for me as an IT manager I didn't need to recalibrate the screens at all. Granted, I spend most of my time looking at text documents, configuration pages for network equipment, and the accounting software my company uses. I couldn't speak to color calibration for individuals doing video or photo production.One thought on the others experiencing washed out colors - HDMI out on a computer kind of expects a TV. Televisions and Monitors will sometimes have different ranges for black levels, which can cause the screen to look washed out. If you're experiencing this, check the control panel for your graphics driver. You should be able to adjust black levels and fix the issue. This has been a driving factor in my preference for just about anything over HDMI. (Display Port is king, for what it's worth.)

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Extremely temperamental - can never disconnect
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2021
text: Long story short: any disconnection from the main monitor makes it extremely difficult to reset the monitor display.I bought two of these to replace my old monitors. I work from home, am in college online, and play some PC games. What I used to do (and was hoping to continue doing) was keep my work laptop connected to the two monitors during the work day, then just switch my work laptop with my personal one and continue using them for school/games.However, ANY kind of disconnection makes it an extreme hassle to get these set back up. I mean any. I disconnected the HDMI cord from my work laptop the first day, and it took 2 hours (of constantly restarting and reconnecting) to get the displays set back up again. I resolved to just use these for work, but I genuinely may have to return them. Even when I just turn off my laptop at night - every morning when I go to turn it all back on at least one of them will not connect (picture is from this morning, just turning my laptop on. This has happened every morning since I’ve gotten these monitors.) and it wouldn’t be as big of a deal if it was just as easy as disconnecting and reconnecting the hdmi cords to reset the displays. But it’s not. I have to restart my computer with the monitors disconnected and powered off, then when my laptop restarts I have to take it off its port and reconnect that, then turn power the monitors on, then connect the hdmi cables. And it takes at least 3-4 times of doing it in that exact order before the monitors finally register that they’re connected and extend my laptop display. That’s an hour every morning just tinkering with a monitor. Which sucks because I spent so much time mounting these things.I’ve never had this issue with any monitors I’ve had in the past. I’m not sure what causes the disruption. I even tried replacing the HDMI cables thinking that may be the cause. But spending an hour each morning restarting my computer to try and get the monitor to register that it is, in fact, connected makes the picture resolution/other perks null and void in my opinion. If you can keep your main monitor/computer constantly turned on then maybe these are good monitors for you. Otherwise I’d suggest another monitor.

title: Quick and easy upgrade, very affordable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 1, 2020
text: Just got replacements - first 2 of these that I ordered arrived smashed.  But replacements arrived an hour ago.This time there was no damage to either monitor.  Took them out and replaced both of the older monitors I was using for home office (thanks to virus, WFH 5 days a week now).  Plugged one into docking stations with VGA, the other with HDMI cable - both connected flawlessly and went right to the correct signal.  They also were correctly detected by Windows and setup automatically to 1920x1080 resolution.As these are being used for IT work, not really pushing the gaming capabilities, but the text and images are displayed very crisply.  Brightness seems just as good as my ASUS gaming monitor that cost over $50 more.  So the value is definitely there.Want to give kudos to Amazon Customer Service.  When ordered they were on back order - expected to get restocked on 3/28, but monitors showed up on the 27th - though smashed.  Contacted Customer Support right away and they issues return shipping and ordered replacements.  At that time they said stock was empty and apologized that replacements would not arrive till after 4/18.  Restock came early, and I got them today 4/1 - very pleasantly surprised.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Great Value - Questionable Quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 19, 2020
text: Like buying a diamond, I checked out the cut, color, clarity, and carats of the SEPTRE 24 inch monitor and it was a great value for half the price of most equivalent screens. I bought one for my wife and it is still working great. I actually had monitor envy, so I bought two for me (dual screen worker).Approximately 70% of Amazon review for this product are fabulous while 30% had various issues...my second experience with these monitors places me firmly into the latter category.Similar to the reviews I read, the screen would go black or would not connect at all to either HDMI port. The two new SCEPTRE monitors had bad HDMI ports: Monitor A had 1 of 2 ports that worked and Monitor B had no working ports. To be fair...1. I tested both new monitors on 3 different laptops (2 Mac, 1 PC) all of which worked 100% with the existing old monitors - these were supposed to be simple monitor upgrades.2. Used 4 different HDMI cables (2 provided with the monitors and 2 currently in use with my current monitors).3. I also tried 2 HDMI to Mini Display cables as well as 2 different adapters - all of which work with other external monitors.4. The one port that did work was loose and if the cable shifted or accidentally got knocked, the monitor would go out.I did reach out directly to SCEPTRE and they were kind, nice, and responded promptly. This was an Amazon purchase so the return was quick and easy.All in all, I do believe this is a good product and a great value. I hope you are in the lucky 70% category. I also hope for SCEPTRE this issue is quickly resolved.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Make sure you have the refresh set to 75hz.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 29, 2022
text: When I first plugged it up the picture was blurry and washed out. I messed with the settings and couldn't quite get it right. Then I thought to check the display properties in windows and noticed it was set to 60hz. As soon as I set it to 75 the picture was great. The neck for the stand is a little more wobbly than I would like, but for the price this monitor is great.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Great value for the price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 9, 2018
text: This monitor works great for any purpose. The IPS panel looks great and is very thin. The instruction manual says that it is a 14ms gray to gray response time. I played Rocket League on it and it ran smooth, I did not have any problems with the response time. The frame is thin but not that much. The audio in and out is a blessing if you want to connect your speakers to it while having more than one monitors, it helps with cable management.  Having two HDMI on the back is great, I would have prefered a DVI instead of the RGB but that's a bit of nitpicking.The monitor does have some bad design choices though. Like someone else said, the AC adapter is bulky and takes a lot of space. I look forward to getting two more in the future to mount them in a VESA mount but I will have to get a multi outlet with enough space for all of the AC adapters. Another thing is that the buttons are on the back. If they could at least put the power button on the front, it would help a great deal. The on-screen display is ok. It gets the job done but since the buttons are on the back, you have to remember where the buttons that navigate the menus are. You need to remember which one is back and which one is accept. A simple label on the OSC reminding you of their order would have helped.I would have given this monitor a 4.5 out of 5 stars but I had to round the score. It is a great monitor for the price but keep those details in mind.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Best for Non-Gaming Purpose
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 16, 2022
text: The picture quality is decent: the darkness level is not so great, the color “black” is more of a gray-ish tone. Brightness level can be adjusted, you can also adjust the colors, but both have limited range. Speakers are poor quality, it reminds me of a retro speaker that my grandpa would play his radio broadcasts, but for the price you pay, you’re getting quite a lot. Especially if you purchase this when it goes on sale. You do get 1080p with 75hz and that’s really more than what you need for an average, “work-at-home” purposes monitor, or for a second monitor screen. If you’re looking for a gaming monitor, you’re on the wrong page. Again, this is definitely not for gaming purposes, but solid enough for work purposes, at home, second monitor, school, documents, and playing few YT videos (not cinema quality) etc.

title: A Great Monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2019
text: I am a writer and I have always used just one computer for all my needs.  However, I decided to add a monitor to write my books on, then do research on the original computer.  This works great for me and this is a great monitor.  Some reviews question the difficulty in using a second monitor.  I can only offer limited experience because I don't do a lot of things with i, only write bookst.  First, it is easy to set up this monitor with the HDMI cable they include.  You simply hook the USB type connections on both ends of the cable to the computer monitor and then to this monitor.  You are ready to go.  I use MS Word to write my books.  To move a book from the original computer to the second computer monitor, I right click on the large blue strip at the top of the Word document, hold it firmly and drag it to this monitor.  Easy to do!  The second monitor has a task bar at the bottom and tool bar at the top to use without being forced to use the computer screen.  This is just like everything in the electronic world, you have to "intuitively" learn to manipulate this second  to suit your needs.  Hope this helps someone!

title: Perfect CHEAP monitor.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
text: I was looking for a cheap monitor upgrade.  I looked for days really hesitant to order because of bad reviews, mainly because of defective products.  I gave in and decided to purchase this 24 inch, 75hrz monitor.  I am glad I did.  This monitor was a huge upgrade.  My old monitor was 21.5 inches with 60 hrz refresh rate.  I notice a huge difference already.  The movement of the mouse alone is way smoother and doesn't lag when moving it around.  The picture is crystal clear, and very sharp quality.  Forgot to mention this but my old monitor didn't have an HDMI port.  This monitor has 2 HDMI ports as well as a VGA port.  There are also built in speakers but I don't use them.  I usually use a headset so the quality of the speakers didn't alter my review of this gem.  Of course, I had to adjust the picture brightness, contrast and gamma to fit my liking, which I do for every monitor I get.  As of now, it works perfectly fine and I love it.  It is safe to say this is the best monitor I have used thus far.  Incredibly cheap, packed with features and runs great!

title: Spend more, skip this.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
text: This monitor is very poor quality, even for the low cost. It lasted only 1 week past 3 months and this morning when we turned it on, the screen is completely white. Tried restarting the computer, changing hdmi cables, trying the other hdmi port, and of course pulling the plug after turning off the monitor with no luck. I couldn’t get anyone to answer on the Sceptre help line, and since Amazon will only help within the first 30 days if it’s unopened, I’ll have to turn to my credit card and ask that they process a charge back. Sceptre claims this has a 1 year warranty, but if you can’t get in contact with them, then obviously there’s no way to process a claim. It just feels like they created a bare minimum monitor to sell and make a quick buck without any QA in place. Then when something goes wrong, they ghost you. Not a recommended product. product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Well packaged and east to setup
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2020
text: I purchased this for my son for school since it's currently virtual.  The poor kid was hunched over looking at the screen on his Chromebook, so I figured the price of the monitor was going to be a lot less than chronic neck pain. The first thing that struck me about this monitor was how well it was packaged inside its box.  I've recently purchased some electronics that were sloppily packaged at the factory.  This thing is packed well enough to easily survive transit from the warehouse to my door without the need for additional boxing.  The second thing that impressed me was the ease of setup.  The monitor has a simple connection to the stand (screwdriver included- I guess some people don't have one already) and came with an HDMI cable.  The image looks great, as it should since we're dealing with a digital signal.  The speakers are more than sufficient for listening to his classes.  The people complaining about the sound quality need to get real.  Be realistic for what they are.

text: Got this as a main/second screen for my macbook air and, so far, works perfect and is totally sick.Set up: Super easy. I went the lightning to HDMI route. Presets for color but you can also dive in and adjust to your taste if you're trying to really dial it in. Me? Nah, the "Cool" setting is doing just fine here. No controls for sound.Sound: That's a "no" for me, dawg. 4 stars (not 5) because the speakers are so shot. Super hollow and tinny sounding. Plugging in headphones? Go straight into your macbook because even plugging beats into this screens sounds like tin trash cans.Random note: I feel like it needs a minute to dial itself in each time I use it. As if it's like "hold up, we starting? ok cool, but let me stretch real quick." Then it feels like it's real on point.Yeah, it's bangin. For $90, get after it.UPDATE: I now have my xbox one in the second HDMI port. Works perfect. Had to adjust the screen color/settings a bit to get it to flow smoother and get all snug. Now we up here. It's bangin.

product_name: Sceptre 24" Professional Thin 75Hz 1080p LED Monitor 2x HDMI VGA Build-in Speakers, Machine Black (E248W-19203R Series)
title: Surprisingly good HDMI monitor!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 10, 2019
text: I purchased two of these displays to use as accessory monitors in my gaming machine (see photo). I spent a significant amount of money on curved MSI 32" 1440p displays as the primary gaming monitors but wanted something smaller and less expensive for the secondary monitors for displaying YouTube videos, Netflix, web pages, etc.After receiving the monitors and using them for a week I have to say I'm really quite pleasantly surprised with both the image on the displays as well as the fit and finish of them. Right out of the box I was pleasantly surprised with the very good packaging and the light weight and thinness of the displays themselves; I've found no dead or stuck pixels so far.Additionally, as you can see, I needed them VESA mounted and when I initially saw the back of them I moaned because they have a mounting stud sticking out of the VESA area for their stands. But a few seconds later I realized that lo-and-behold Sceptre had included standoffs and hardware necessary to accomplish a VESA mount! They even included a small screwdriver! They could have cheaped out on including that hardware (my expensive MSI curved displays did and are not VESA mountable out of the box) but these little guys didn't. Good show, Sceptre.I haven't used the stands so I cannot comment on those, but text is clear, color is good and the built-in menus are simple and effective. I have to say, for a monitor at this price-point I'm pretty impressed.

text: Looking for a monitor for gaming on a PS5 and working with my laptop I finally decided to purchase an inexpensive monitor and use it until I get the PS5 ( and a new laptop, maybe 🤔)First, the monitor is nice, with thin bezels. I light easy to move, the stand (or base) is plastic and very light, a heavier stand is better, without it the monitor move or shakes too much.The image is ok, good for office work but not for today’s games.Sound, it have two speakers, terrible speakers with weak sound, I can accept that on a monitor this cheap but it also have an audio out, for headphones or speakers, I tried my audio technical and they sound weak, using a line amplifier will solve this.Big problem - just received and installed it, no image, not even the sceptre logo, then I notice that the power LED eas off, I tried an universal power suppliy and everything is working.I contacted Amazon, they offer to replace the monitor, I declined the offer, since is working fine and send it back is a waste of time and money for something this cheap.I contacted sceptre, ask them for a new power brick, no response so far 👎.  I just ordered another universal power supply.Overall is not a bad monitor for the price, just some issues with sound and quality control. Recommended but be careful.
